questions.text: Which drug is used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A – Buprenorph

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 40-year-old male patient who was admitted to the ICU three days ago due to breathing difficulty and is currently experiencing restlessness and widespread tremors? The patient has reported seeing insects crawling on his bed and body and has had one seizure, which was successfully managed with lorazepam. Further investigation reveals that the patient is a chronic alcoholic.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Delirium tremens.

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

questions.explanation:
Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

(Option A ruled out)

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

  • Severe agitation

  • Profound sweating

questions.text: Jet black pigmentation of the tongue with tactile hallucinations is a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Cocaine

Category

Description

Source

Derived from the leaves of the coca plant (Erythroxylum coca).

Mechanism of Action
  • Inhibits presynaptic transporters of NE, DA, and 5-HT.
  • Blocks neurotransmitter reuptake, increasing synaptic levels and enhancing postsynaptic effects.

Methods of Use
  • Snorting: Inhalation through the nose; less dangerous than other methods.
  • Injection: Subcutaneous or intravenous; high risk of overdose, cardiac issues.
  • Smoking: Crack cocaine or freebasing; most dangerous, intense addiction and behavioural changes.
  • Oral Use: Rare and ineffective.

Combination Use

Cocaine + Heroin = "Speed Balls."

Intoxication Effects

Euphoria, hyperactivity, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, dilated pupils, acute cardiovascular risks.

Adverse Effects

Hypertension, tachycardia, myocardial ischemia/infarction, seizures, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, paranoia.

Cocaine Withdrawal
  • Symptoms: Cravings, anhedonia, dysphoria, hypersomnia, irritability, increased appetite.
  • No physical complications (e.g., seizures).

Cocaine-Induced Psychosis
  • Paranoid delusions and hallucinations (auditory > tactile/visual).
  • Formication ("cocaine bugs").
  • More common in men and IV/crack cocaine users.

Treatment for Withdrawal
  • Supportive care for mood symptoms and suicidal ideation.
  • Behavioral interventions like CBT for relapse prevention.

Treatment for Psychosis

Short-term antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who underwent appendectomy 7 hours ago and is currently experiencing auditory hallucinations and confusion about the source of the voices? The patient maintains orientation, and his vital signs are stable. Upon inquiry, his wife reveals that he occasionally consumes alcohol.
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

questions.text: Which of the following drug abuses can lead to the symptoms described by a 25-year-old male patient who complains of a sensation resembling insects crawling beneath his skin and has presented to the clinic?
questions.explanation:
Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Erythroxylum coca plant

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted, Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment approach for a known alcoholic patient who is brought to the emergency department in a disoriented state and complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin?
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal

 
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)

 
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold. (Option A and D ruled out)

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis) (Option D)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

questions.text: What is a true statement about nicotine substitution therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death

options.label: C
options.text: There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption

options.label: D
options.text: Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.correct_answer: C. There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Nicotine addiction

Therapy

Description

Nicotine gum
  • Smokers can use 1-2 gums per hour and a maximum of 24 gums per day.
  • It releases nicotine by chewing and buccal absorption.
  • Beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice should not be used during gum use because they decrease absorption.
  • Poor compliance is a drawback.

Nicotine lozenges
  • Users must suck the lozenges until it is completely dissolved and must not swallow it.
  • Useful for people who smoke immediately after awakening.
  • It provides the highest level of nicotine compared to other nicotine replacement therapies.

﻿﻿Nicotine patches
  • Attached to the skin
  • Continuous delivery of nicotine and is available as 16 or 24-hour tapering preparations.
  • It has good compliance.

﻿﻿Nicotine nasal spray
  • Provides nicotine concentration in the blood similar to
    Smoking.
  • Major adverse effects are rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing

﻿﻿Nicotine inhaler
  • Nicotine absorption occurs in the upper throat, not the lungs

Non-nicotine medications
  • ﻿﻿Bupropion (an antidepressant): It has dopaminergic and adrenergic actions.
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline is a partial agonist of alpha-4 beta-2 nicotinic receptors.
    • It blocks nicotine from binding to the receptor and decreases the rewarding aspects of cigarette smoking.
    • It also stimulates the receptor and reduces withdrawal and cravings.
    • Comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline (Second-line drug)
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine: It decreases the sympathetic activity from locus ceruleus and is useful in controlling withdrawal symptoms.

Nicotine replacement therapy

Non-nicotine medications
  • Nicotine gum
  • Nicotine lozenges
  • Nicotine patches
  • Nicotine nasal spray
  • Nicotine inhaler
  • Bupropion
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Korsakoff syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of long-term memory but intact personality

options.label: C
options.text: Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
questions.explanation:
Wernicke's encephalopathy

Korsakoff psychosis

Neurological disorder which occurs due to thiamine deficiency

Results from untreated Wernicke encephalopathy

Occurs due to alcohol abuse, nutritional habits or malabsorption.

Chronic alcoholism

Presents with acute symptoms like problems with eye movement (nystagmus), coordination (ataxia), and confusion.

Presents with impaired mental syndrome - recent memory, Anterograde amnesia and Confabulation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient? Diazepam Thiamine Naltrexone Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold.

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioral approaches are recommended.

questions.text: What is the predominant manifestation experienced with cannabis consumption?
questions.explanation:
Cannabis

Aspect

Description

Composition
  • Over 400 compounds
  • Includes cannabinoids, flavonoids, and terpenoids
  • Primary psychoactive component: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)

Forms
  • Dried plant material (marijuana)
  • Bhang (Derived from dried leaves)
  • Ganja (derived from flowering stem)
  • Hashish (concentrated resin)
  • Oils and extracts (Hash oil)
  • Edibles
  • Topical preparations

Receptors
  • CB1 and CB2 (G-protein coupled receptors- Gi subtype)

Methods of Use
  • Smoking (most common)
  • Vaporizing
  • Oral ingestion
  • Sublingual administration
  • Topical application

Clinical Features of Intoxication
  • Tachycardia
  • Conjunctival injection
  • Anxiety or euphoria
  • Slowness of time
  • Impaired cognition and motor coordination
  • Dry mouth
  • Increased appetite
  • Nystagmus
  • Postural hypotension
  • Delirium (especially at high doses)

Onset and Duration of Effects
  • Smoking: Rapid onset (minutes), duration 2-3 hours
  • Oral ingestion: Delayed onset (30-90 minutes), duration 4-12 hours

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the hospital with auditory hallucinations and inability to recognize his own family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Minor withdrawal

• Mild anxiety

• Tremulousness

• Nausea

• Headache

• Palpitations

6-12 hours

Alcoholic hallucinosis (Option B)

• Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations

• Intact orientation

• Normal vital signs

12-24 hours

Withdrawal seizures

• Generalized tonic-clonic seizures

• Usually brief and self-limited

• Also known as rum fits

24-48 hours

Delirium tremens

• Severe agitation

• Confusion and disorientation

• Hallucinations (often visual)

• Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)

• Profound sweating

• Tremors

• Insomnia

48-96 hours

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic alcoholic who began binge drinking ten days ago is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. A CT scan of his brain is normal, but his blood glucose level is 45 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.correct_answer: B. IM Thiamine followed by dextrose
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - IM Thiamine

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room, reporting that she ingested an unknown substance. She presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C – C

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident (RTA). He presents with confusion, irritability, and tremors. The patient has a history of daily alcohol consumption. Which drug is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal symptoms in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - L

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with diplopia and ataxia, and he was completely confused. A history of alcohol was noted. What is the initial treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Wernicke's Encephalopathy Korsakoff Syndrome
Onset Acute Chronic often follows Wernicke's syndrome
Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine (Option B)

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 20-year history of chronic alcohol consumption, averaging 500 ml daily, presents to the clinic with complaints of sensations of insects crawling on his skin, agitation, and irritation. He reports that his last drink was 3 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Stage of Alcohol Withdrawal

Symptoms

Onset After Last Drink

Treatment

Mild Withdrawal

Mild anxiety, tremulousness, nausea, headache, palpitations

6-8 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam). Carbamazepine (800 mg daily).

Moderate (Alcoholic Hallucinosis)

Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations, intact orientation, normal vital signs

8-12 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).

Severe (Withdrawal Seizures)

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures, usually brief and self-limited (rum fits)

12-24 hours

Benzodiazepines (Treatment of choice).

Anticonvulsants not more beneficial.

Life-Threatening (Delirium Tremens)

Severe agitation, confusion, disorientation, visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, profound sweating, tremors, insomnia

Within 72 hours

Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV). Supportive care (high-calorie diet, multivitamins).

Haloperidol for severe agitation (caution with seizure threshold).

Protracted Withdrawal

Symptoms may last 2-6 months

-

Acamprosate is recommended for symptom relief, and cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to define dependence: a. Strong desire to use the drug b. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity c. Increased tolerance d. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - a, b, c, d

Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioural Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviours and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterised by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption is admitted to the hospital with features of confusion, vision loss and an unsteady gait . He is unable to remember the most recent incidents. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct option C - Thiamine (Vitamin B1)

questions.text: Consider the following statements Statement 1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking Statement 2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to their health Statement 3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then Statement 4-Action phase- A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Statements 1 and 3 are correct:

Precontemplation

(Statement 2 ruled out)

  • The individual is not considering a change in behaviour in the foreseeable future.

  • They may be unaware or in denial about the need for change.

Contemplation

(Statement 1)

  • The individual recognises the problem and is considering change but is not yet ready to take action.

Preparation

  • The individual is intending to take action shortly (usually within the next 30 days)

  • May have started taking small steps toward change.

Action

(Statement 4 ruled out)

  • The individual has recently made changes (within the last 6 months)

  • Actively working to maintain those changes.

Maintenance

(Statement 3)

  • The individual has sustained their behaviour change for more than 6 months

  • Working to prevent relapse.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a chronic alcoholic who arrives at the emergency department presenting confusion, ataxia, painful eye movements, and involvement of the 6 th cranial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Wernicke's Encephalopathy

(Option A)

Korsakoff Syndrome

(Option B ruled out)

Onset

Acute

Chronic, often follows Wernicke's

Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

questions.text: Which drug among the options provided would assist a chronic smoker in their aim to quit smoking ?

options.label: D

questions.explanation: Correct Option C - V
